title-group.article-title: Optimizing Coronary CT Image Reconstruction With Deep Learning for Improved Quality: A Retrospective Study

article-meta.aff: *Department of General Radiology, Interventional Radiology, and Neuroradiology, Wroclaw Medical University, Wroclaw, Poland
†Department of Radiology, University Clinical Hospital of Jan Mikulicz-Radecki in Wroclaw, Wroclaw, Poland

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence to: Agata Zdanowicz-Ratajczyk, MD, Department of General Radiology, Interventional Radiology, and Neuroradiology, Wroclaw Medical University, Borowska 213, Wrocław 50-556, Poland (e-mail: agata.zdanowicz@student.umw.edu.pl).

The work cannot be changed in any way or used commercially without permission from the journal.

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To evaluate the impact of deep learning image reconstruction on image quality in CCTA compared with adaptive statistical iterative reconstruction (ASIR).

sec.title: Materials and Methods:
sec.p: CCTA data sets from 100 consecutive patients with suspected CAD were acquired with a Revolution Apex 256-row CT scanner, reconstructed with ASIR-V and DLIR-H, and subsequently analyzed. Image noise, SNR, and CNR in five regions of interest (25 mm) were calculated and t tested. The normality of quantitative variables was assessed using the Shapiro-Wilk test. For non-normally distributed data, the Mann-Whitney U test was applied. The concordance of HU values within specific ROIs was analyzed with Bland-Altman plots. Correlation between ASIR-V and DLIR-H was conducted using the Spearman rank correlation test.

Subjective image analysis was conducted using a 5-point scale to evaluate noise level, vascular enhancement smoothness, artifact reduction, and diagnostic confidence. Intraclass correlation (ICC) was used to assess the reliability and consistency of subjective ratings among the reader.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: DLIR-H significantly reduced image noise across all ROIs (from 15% to 41%, all P<0.05), compared with ASIR-V. Mean SNR (ASIR-V vs. DLIR-H) were septum=4.3±1.7 versus 6.4±2.2; cavity of the left ventricle=24.3±8.3 versus 36.6±11.7; CNR: septum=8.2±2.5 versus 12.4±3.5; cavity of left ventricle= 28.2±9.1 versus 42.5±13.0. Spearman rank correlation ranged from 0.64 to 0.79 (P<0.05). Bland-Altman analysis showed good agreement between ASIR-V and DLIR-H, with no discernible patterns. Subjectively, DLIR-H significantly outperformed ASIR-V across all evaluated criteria (all P<0.05). ICC values indicated strong agreement among readers, demonstrating excellent reliability for most criteria and good reliability for vascular enhancement smoothness.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: DLIR-H significantly improved CCTA image quality compared with ASIR-V, which contributes to a more accurate diagnosis in patients with suspected CAD.

kwd-group.title: Abbreviations:
kwd-group.kwd: ASIRV = adaptive statistical iterative reconstruction-very enhanced optimization
DLIR-H = deep learning image reconstruction at a high level

institution-wrap.institution: Uniwersytet Medyczny im. Piastów Slaskich we Wroclawiu

body.p: Coronary computed tomography angiography (CCTA) has become a widely recognized non-invasive diagnostic tool for the evaluation of patients with suspected coronary artery disease (CAD).1 Accurate diagnosis of CAD relies on the precision of imaging techniques, underscoring the critical need to optimize CCTA image quality for enhanced diagnostic efficacy. Insufficient X-ray tube power in CCTA can compromise image quality by introducing interfering noise.2 To address this problem adaptive statistical iterative reconstruction (ASIR) has been introduced, demonstrating improved noise reduction and reproducibility compared with conventional filtered back projection (FBP).3,4 ASIR can effectively reduce noise in CCTA images, but it often introduces an oversmoothing phenomenon that results in the loss of fine detail and blurring of structures. The degree of oversmoothing increases in proportion to the strength of the iterative reconstruction (IR), requiring novel reconstruction algorithms to maintain a balance between minimizing image noise and preserving texture.5

Recent advancements in deep learning image reconstruction (DLIR) have demonstrated remarkable potential in improving CCTA image quality by leveraging deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs).6,7 Trained on vast data sets of both low-dose and high-dose FBP images, DLIR excels at generating high-quality images through an iterative refinement process.8 A key advantage of DLIR lies in its ability to preserve texture fidelity while simultaneously reducing slice thickness. DLIR effectively counteracts the increased noise associated with thinner slices in CCTA, thus enhancing spatial resolution without compromising diagnostic accuracy.10,11 Its ability to distinguish between true pathology and artifacts and suppress spectral artifacts is particularly promising in challenging scenarios involving extensive coronary calcification or stents.12–15

For these reasons, the present study aimed to investigate the impact of the DLIR on the image quality of coronary CT angiography in patients with suspected CAD using objective metrics namely signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR), and image noise.

sec.title: Study Population
sec.p: This observational, retrospective, single-center study was approved by the local ethics committee and performed according to the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice. Written informed consent was obtained from all patients. Data sets of 123 consecutive patients who underwent clinically indicated contrast-enhanced multislice CCTA between July 2019 and July 2022 were retrieved and subsequently analyzed.

Inclusion criteria were adult age (18 years or older), CAD as the primary cause of diagnostic tests (defined according to the criteria of the European Society of Cardiology [ESC] guidelines),1 and written informed consent provided by the patient. CCTA images were analyzed retrospectively. Participants were excluded from the study based on exclusion criteria, which are detailed in Figure 1. As a result, a total of 100 patients were included in the analysis.

sec.title: Coronary CT Angiography Acquisition
sec.p: All 100 data sets were acquired by Revolution Apex 256-row scanner (GE Healthcare, Chicago, IL). Imaging was performed using the axial scanning method. The scan range covered the entire thorax in an ECG-gated acquisition with a 75% contrast phase. The details of the scanning parameters are shown in Table 1.

sec.title: Coronary CT Angiography Reconstruction
sec.p: All data sets were transferred to a dedicated postprocessing workstation (Advantage Workstation 4.7; GE Healthcare) through a picture archiving and communication system (PACS). The process included curved planar reconstruction. The image reconstruction was performed using a deep neural network engine trained on high-quality FBP images for DLIR (TrueFidelity; GE Healthcare) where the DLIR at a high level (DLIR-H) was applied. The ASIR reconstruction was carried out using a combination of 50% adaptive statistical iterative reconstruction—very enhanced optimization (ASIR-V) and 50% FBP in the latest generation of iterative reconstruction protocol provided by the vendor.

sec.title: Objective Image Quality Assessment
sec.p: All data sets were evaluated at Advantage Workstation 4.7, GE Healthcare using image noise, SNR, and CNR in 5 circle-shaped regions of interest (ROIs) (25 mm2). To ensure consistency, a control variable was established using manually placed ROIs representing predefined study areas in each image pair and duplicated on the DLIR-V reconstructed images (Fig. 2), minimizing potential variation due to tissue inhomogeneity. Four ROIs were placed in the mediastinum region: upper one-third of the intraventricular septum, cavity of the left ventricle, descending aorta, and pericardial fat (Fig. 2). Additional ROI was set in the air above the patient’s sternum.

caption.p: Regions of interest (ROIs, blue circles) on DLIR-H and corresponding ASIR-V reconstructed images of coronary CT. ROI 1 indicates upper one-third of the intraventricular septum; ROI 2, pericardial fat; ROI 3, left ventricle cavity; ROI 4, descending aorta; ROI 5, air.

sec.p: Image noise was defined as the SD of the CT density at the selected ROI. Although there are no standardized cutoff values for image noise, some authors suggest a value ≤30 Hounsfield units (HU) to improve the quality of coronary CTA.16
Given the stable attenuation and homogeneity of the fat, it was chosen as the background ROI, providing a consistent signal intensity for comparison with other ROIs.16
The SNR was derived by computing the average attenuation value in signal ROI divided by the SD measured within the background ROI.
For the selected ROI pairs, CNR was determined with the use of formula 1:
Formula 1. Equation for the contrast-to-ratio (CNR). Avg: average; background ROI: pericardial fat.

The tissue differentiation properties were evaluated by calculating the CNR for myocardium, air, and pericardial fat to assess the accuracy of ASIR-V and DLIR-H in differentiating tissues with naturally contrasting X-ray attenuation properties.

sec.title: Subjective Image Quality Assessment
sec.p: The subjective quality of coronary CT images was assessed by 3 readers with different levels of experience in cardiac radiology (2, 3, and 7 y, respectively). Each of the 100 anonymized image data sets was reviewed using Advantage Workstation 4.7 (GE Healthcare). Images were presented to each reader in a unique, randomized order to minimize recall bias. Each reader independently graded images reconstructed using both ASIR-V and DLIR-H for all 100 patients, without knowledge of the reconstruction method.

Readers rated 4 image quality parameters on a standardized 5-point scale: 5=excellent, 4=satisfactory, 3=acceptable, 2=suboptimal, and 1=inadequate. Criteria included acceptable noise level, vascular enhancement smoothness, artifact reduction, and overall diagnostic confidence. All assessments were performed in a blinded manner, with readers unaware of the reconstruction technique, to eliminate potential bias.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: The statistical analysis was performed using STATISTICA 13 (StatSoft, Tulsa, OK). Continuous variables with a normal distribution were presented as mean±SD. The normality of quantitative variables was assessed using the Shapiro-Wilk test. A paired, 2-tailed Student t test was conducted for normally distributed data to assess the statistical significance of differences between the ASIR-V and DLIR-H reconstruction methods in estimating SNR and CNR, and subjective image quality ratings. In cases where the data did not follow a normal distribution, the Mann-Whitney U test was used.

Correlation analysis for values with non-normal distribution was conducted using the Spearman rank correlation test where 0.1 to 0.29 indicates a poor correlation, 0.3 to 0.59 a fair correlation, 0.6 to 0.79 a moderate correlation, 0.8 to 0.99 a strong correlation, and 1 indicates a perfect correlation.17

To assess the agreement between the conventional technique (ASIR-V) and the novel approach (DLIR-H) Bland-Altman plots were used to visually represent the concordance of Hounsfield unit (HU) values within specific ROIs.
The intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) was calculated to assess the reliability and consistency of the subjective image quality ratings among the 3 readers.
A P-value of <0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: The results of the quantitative image quality analysis are shown in Table 2. Overall, the SNR and CNR were significantly higher after DLIR-H, with all differences being statistically significant.

caption.p: The Quantitative Image Quality of CCTA With ASIR-V and DLIR-H in Selected ROI

fn.p: CNR indicates contrast-to-noise ratio; ROIs—1: upper one-third of the intraventricular septum of the heart, 2: pericardial fat (background ROI), 3: cavity of the left ventricle, 4: descending aorta, 5: air; SNR, signal-to-noise ratio.

sec.title: Signal-to-Noise Ratio
sec.p: SNR values for both ASIR-V and DLIR-H are shown in Figure 3. DLIR-H demonstrated a significant and consistent 51% (P<0.05) increase in SNR across all ROIs, except for the descending aorta where the SNR increased by 47% (P<0.05).

caption.p: Signal-to-noise ratio for ASIR-V (blue) and DLIR-H (yellow) in selected ROIs. ROI 1 indicates upper one-third of the intraventricular septum; ROI 2, pericardial fat; ROI 3, left ventricle cavity; ROI 4, descending aorta; ROI 5, air.

sec.title: Contrast-to-Noise Ratio
sec.p: The CNR values for the selected ROIs in ASIR-V and DLIR-H are shown in Figure 4. DLIR-H consistently yielded higher CNR values than ASIR-V for all ROIs examined.

caption.p: Contrast-to-noise ratio for ASIR-V (blue) and DLIR-H (yellow) in selected ROIs. ROI 1 indicates upper one-third of the intraventricular septum; ROI 2, pericardial fat; ROI 3, left ventricle cavity; ROI 4, descending aorta; ROI 5, air.

sec.p: The improvement in CNR with DLIR-H ranged from 48% to 51% for the descending aorta and intraventricular septum as well as left ventricular cavity, respectively, and all changes were statistically significant (P<0.05).

sec.title: Image Noise
sec.p: The DLIR-H implementation significantly reduced image noise compared with ASIR-V in all anatomic regions, with a relative change ranging from 15% in the air to 41% in the left ventricular cavity and descending aorta, all P<0.05 (Table 3).

caption.p: Image Noise of CCTA With ASIR-V and DLIR-H in Selected ROI

fn.p: ROIs—1 indicates upper one-third of the intraventricular septum of the heart, 2: pericardial fat (background ROI), 3: cavity of the left ventricle, 4: descending aorta, 5: air.

sec.title: Correlation Analysis
sec.p: The Spearman rank correlation coefficients of CNR as presented in Table 4 ranged from 0.64 (ROI 5 vs. ROI 2) to 0.79 (ROI 3 vs. ROI 2) suggesting a moderate correlation between ASIR-V and DLIR-H (P<0.05).

caption.p: The Spearman Rank Coefficient for CNR in ASIR-V and DLIR-H

fn.p: ROIs—1: upper one-third of the intraventricular septum of the heart, 2: pericardial fat (background ROI), 3: cavity of the left ventricle, 4: descending aorta, 5: air.

sec.title: Bland-Altman Analysis
sec.p: The Bland-Altman analysis of the selected ROIs presented in Table 5, revealed a uniform dispersion of data points (Fig. 5). The majority of the data points fell within the limits of agreement, indicating reasonable agreement between the 2 methods. There were no discernible patterns or trends in the data.

caption.p: Bland-Altman Plot Analysis of DLIR-H and ASIR- V

fn.p: ROI 1 indicates one-third of upper intraventricular septum; ROI 2, pericardial fat; ROI 3, left ventricle cavity; ROI 4, descending aorta; ROI 5-air.

caption.p: Comparative agreement analysis of DLIR-H versus ASIR-V in coronary CT: A Bland-Altman plot in selected ROIs. ROI 1 indicates upper one-third of the intraventricular septum; ROI 2, pericardial fat; ROI 3, left ventricle cavity; ROI 4, descending aorta; ROI 5, air.

sec.title: Subjective Image Quality Analysis
sec.p: DLIR-H was superior to ASIR-V in all selected criteria of the subjective image analysis (Table 6). The DLIR-H reconstructions demonstrated superior vascular enhancement smoothness (4.2±0.6) compared with ASIR-V (3.7±0.7), more acceptable noise levels (4.0±0.7 vs. 3.3±0.8), and fewer artifacts (4.0±0.7 vs. 3.6±0.8), resulting in improved overall diagnostic confidence (4.3±0.6 vs. 3.7±0.7).

caption.p: Subjective Image Quality Assessment of CCTA Reconstructed With ASIR-V and DLIR-H

fn.p: Analysis was performed by 3 readers using a 5-point scale (1=inadequate, 5=excellent).

sec.title: The Intraclass Correlation Coefficient
sec.p: The ICC values demonstrate strong agreement among the 3 readers in assessing the subjective image quality of coronary CT images, with excellent reliability for most criteria, such as acceptable noise level (0.83), natural appearance (0.84), and overall diagnostic confidence (0.88). Vascular enhancement smoothness showed good reliability (0.79), confirming consistent and robust ratings across all criteria.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Our study confirms that DLIR-H significantly enhances CCTA image quality, consistently outperforming ASIR-V in both objective and subjective metrics. Specifically, DLIR-H achieved a substantial 51% improvement in SNR across all anatomic regions, with a notable 47% increase in the descending aorta (all P<0.05). In addition, DLIR-H resulted in a 48% to 51% improvement in CNR (Fig. 4) and a 15% to 41% reduction in image noise.
A subjective analysis further validated the superiority of the DLIR-H in terms of image quality determinants.

Comprehensive analysis of CCTA image quality cannot be captured by a single metric, as it involves balancing various factors such as noise reduction, vascular enhancement, and control over coronary motion artifacts. While spatial resolution quantifies image detail, our study demonstrates that DLIR-H’s improvements in SNR and CNR offer more valuable insights for interpreting coronary CT images, particularly by enhancing diagnostic confidence and improving visualization of coronary structures.

Using deep convolutional neural networks, DLIR-H effectively captures complex spatial features within the image data, distinguishing between noise and true signal.18 In regions of higher tissue density, such as the septum and left ventricle, DLIR-H further enhances already detectable signals, contributing to a more accurate representation of the underlying anatomic structures. The reduction in image noise, combined with improved resolution, enables more accurate differentiation of subtle details, particularly in low-contrast regions such as coronary plaque.9,19
These synergistic improvements significantly enhance image quality, facilitating a more accurate assessment of atherosclerotic plaque and stenosis severity in CCTA (Fig. 6).

caption.p: Comparison of coronary CT imaging reconstructed with ASIR-V and DLIR-H. An 80-year-old male with a clinical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presented to the outpatient clinic with chest pain. The patient underwent a CT examination with a calcium score evaluation. Coronary artery calcium score: 5149 (LM: 713 j.A, 232 mm3, LAD: 2018 j.A, 701 mm3, LCx: 658 j.A, 221 mm3, RCA: 1760 j.A, 593 mm3).

sec.p: Furthermore, the moderate positive correlation between ASIR-V and DLIR-H, with statistically significant Spearman rank correlation coefficients ranging from 0.64 to 0.79 (P<0.05), confirms a consistent direct relationship between the 2 methods, highlighting their interdependence. Bland-Altman analysis of the selected ROIs (Fig. 5) demonstrated a high degree of agreement between the 2 reconstruction methods, with only minor discrepancies observed.

Our results in a large group of patients (n=100) are consistent with the existing literature, which suggests that DLIR is effective in minimizing image noise in CCTA compared with IR methods.14,18,20 Several studies have shown that earlier DLIR algorithms offer favorable noise texture,21 better sharpness,22 superior image quality (when compared with ASIR-V),23 and superior spatial resolution than high-quality model-based IR images.24 In our study, we evaluated the latest reconstruction method, DLIR at a high level, confirming the advancements in image quality.

Furthermore, DLIR has been shown to improve image quality in head and neck dual-energy CTA,23 especially in the visualization of intracranial arteries in obese patients undergoing CCTA,25,26 and in lower extremity arteries,22 and does not affect the assessment of coronary stenosis.18,20 These findings may indicate the feasibility of DLIR also in the evaluation of coronary arteries. DLIR significantly reduces image noise in low-dose chest CT scans,27 which is critical for CCTA, where high-resolution, low-noise imaging is essential for the accurate diagnosis of coronary abnormalities. Noise reduction is particularly beneficial for visualizing low-contrast areas, such as plaque and coronary artery stenosis.20 Moreover, DLIR’s contribution to high-resolution imaging enhances spatial resolution,28 facilitating precise delineation of the boundaries of small and dense structures, like calcified arterial walls. Importantly, improved resolution aids in mitigating beam-hardening artifacts commonly associated with high-density materials, like stents.
The effectiveness of DLIR is demonstrated by the reduced variability in CT values between luminal sections within and adjacent to stents.

Our study has several limitations. We evaluated CCTA image quality and not the diagnostic accuracy for CAD. Given the homogeneity of the patient group, our findings may not fully represent the efficacy of DLIR in different medical conditions.
Although DLIR results in a radiation dose reduction, we did not compare conventional and lower-dose images. Future research should determine the clinical utility of DLIR in low-dose imaging.

Furthermore, the evaluation of image quality based primarily on linear metrics such as CNR and SNR has limitations, especially in cases that require nonlinear analysis, such as visualization of complex coronary plaques, identification of subtle lesions in low-contrast areas, and delineation of small vessels. Incorporating more sophisticated assessment techniques, such as the detectability index (d’) and metrics based on the modulation transfer function (MTF) or task-based transfer function (TTF)/noise power spectrum (NPS), could provide a more comprehensive understanding of image quality, leading to a more robust evaluation of our results.29 Further research is required to confirm these findings.

In conclusion, DLIR-H significantly improved image quality in CCTA compared with ASIR-V. This improvement may facilitate the visualization of plaque and stenosis and lead to more accurate diagnoses in patients with suspected CAD.

fn.p: The research was supported from the statutory grant for the Department of Radiology, Wroclaw Medical University, Poland, SUB Z. C270.25.092.
The authors declare no conflict of interest.
